ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Ziv Eisenberg  The Best TF I have encountered. Sometimes felt that the TA sessions were more thought provoking than class sessions. He is amazing and very helpful.
Instructor: Ziv Eisenberg  There was only one TF for this course.
Instructor: Ziv Eisenberg  I did not interact much with Ziv because I attended the discussion sections led by Prof. Wyman.
Instructor: Ziv Eisenberg  Ziv

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Best class I have taken so far at Yale. I have gained immensely from this course. I would take it again and again if I was allowed.

Too much of the course was on the professor's personal theory (aka humans are chimps so all behavior can be directly linked between the 2 species) and not nearly enough was on actual population issues, like immigration, urbanization, food crises, etc etc. It was not a graduate level course and should not have been offered as such.

This class was very poorly taught and disorganized. Despite having lengthy verbatim notes, the professor still managed to meander, re-tell pieces repeatedly, and veer the course off pace. I was very disappointed at the almost total neglect of environmental issues associated with population growth, which was my primary reason for taking the class; the one day that we spent on the topic the professor used to present evidence for increasing levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. No one at Yale needs to be convinced of this. This was one prime example of a pattern of belaboring basic points and neglecting the larger, more challenging, and more interesting issues.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Lectures, Readings, TF sections. The material being taught is so interesting that you're begging for more by the end.

There were some interesting concepts when we actually talked about population, like the different forms of population/fertility control used by different cultures and their impacts on the growth rate.
The material in the reading was very useful for gaining a better understanding of the lessons.
The breadth of topics that we covered was extensive, and this made the course very interesting.

Interesting course topic, many good readings, although the reading list clearly has not been updated recently as most are dated. Unfortunately, the teaching was so poor that it completely overturned what should have been a fascinating class, and one that I was very excited to take.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think it could do with better organization of material.

More modern material. The vast majority of the articles were at least 15 years old and it would have been interesting to see some of the older case studies updated, like the Bangladesh case. It's weird to have so much material be significantly older than me (I'm 23), particularly in a class where so many topics are ongoing and past successes may have become failures and vice versa. Leaving things at the mid-90s assessment is ridiculous.Further, cut out the ape stuff. That was clearly a pet theory and should have been presented with much more qualifications instead of as gospel. Evolutionary psychology needs much better support than that to be appropriate for a (theoretically) graduate school course. It took up valuable time and was inappropriate by normal standards of psychology and primatology - no one talks like that about humans any more.Also, there are lots of interesting professors who could be brought in as guest speakers on some ofthis stuff. I was disappointed that, although Yale professors were mentioned as authors of studies, they weren't ever brought in to speak.Finally, the way the professor kept calling on non-Caucasian students to explain "their culture" was inappropriate and it made me extremely uncomfortable. Students could volunteer to speak about something if it seemed relevant to their own experiences but calling on students to explain long-outdated practices of a country they may or may not be from is extremely insensitive. I don't think he meant any harm by it but it was really inappropriate and would happen at least twice a class.

I was often uncomfortable with the way the professor went about talking about subject matter by using personal stories and experiences. I don't think personal commentary is necessary, the professor should stick more strictly to the material.The class also seemed to be disorganized at times, often running overtime and still not completing the lesson for the day.

The class, as taught now, just isn't a graduate level course. It's cross listed with MCDB, and is a sophomore level undergraduate class. The concepts that Professor Wyman raised, and the issues that he discussed, were interesting and important issues--but were mostly issues that graduate students would already be familiar with.It's also really not an environmental class. I understand that human population growth has vital impacts on the environment, but we barely discussed this aspect of human population growth (which is why I took the class). There were essentially two lectures on the environment: The first covered the basic of CO2 increase and global warming, and the second was essentially a wrap-up of the entire semester.As such, though the course is valuable to some people, I don't think it should be cross-listed with FES again, unless some changes are made to the difficulty of the course and the subject matter.
The lectures sometimes had a lot of detail, making it hard for me to extract the main points out of the lecture. But having the lectures available later definitely helped.

The professor's conduct during this class was apalling. I have never felt so disrespected as I have in Prof. Wyman's class. He was rudely dismissive of students that challenged any of his points (and his particular use of data and the sweeping conclusions he drew certainly left the door open for challenges). He spoke derisively about students in our class behind their backs to a student discussion session. I felt personally disrespected by the way he responded to my analysis in class, to the point that I fear retribution in his grading.He wants to tell a particular story in a particular way, and anyone who attempts to think critically about that story is rudely brushed aside. He also insisted on belaboring very basic points, and would silence students that tried to summarize the issue and move discussion along to the more pertinent issues. Finally, he made several problematic and/or offensive statements. For instance, during one discussion session, he told us about how he once "lived in the ghetto" and took it upon himself to "teach those little black children how to speak proper English" and how he would then return to his white friends and "talk black to them and they really got a kick out of that."The University needs to think long and hard about whether they really support this kind of behavior.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The best section. No need for improvement. Ziv has been great.
The discussion was entirely up to students to lead so there was effectiveness and relation to class depending on how the students approached the discussion.
NA

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: He is the best I've seen. His teaching method does not need change. If any, the technology used in section needs improvement.
Instructor: Ziv Eisenberg  He was very nice and helpful and seemed to understand the plight of the students given the professor.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I hoped to get some insight into human population issues and programs. I got some but was really disappointed by how outdated the material was and how little it was tied in to any other discipline/modern issue. There was a really half-hearted attempt to bring up climate change but it was terribly done.
I thought it would fit nicely, but the content ended up being so remedial that I don't think it ended up being very valuable at all, and didn't present any clearly new material.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Out of interest in developing economy issues, this topic is of immense importance to our world.
It seemed interesting at the time. I regret it, honestly.
I believed it would be helpful in my future work.

I was hoping to get a better feel for how to deal with population growth in an environmental context--how do you encourage people to have fewer children, and how can their impacts on the environment be mitigated, while still increasing standard of living?
I was interested in the variety of topics on the syllabus, and particularly the environmental effects of population growth.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: More than exceeded my expectations

No. Not even close. This should not be a graduate level course, which is unfortunate since the over all concepts are important and aren't well represented at FES. Perhaps a more effective way to get the same material in would be to have some kind of a lecture about how human population growth impacts the rest of the material in each of the courses offered here.
I would have liked to have had more focus on the environment and impacts of population on the environment.

We gained a thorough understanding of the causes of population growth, as well as effective strategies for incorporating family planning programs in diverse cultures--but never really got to the environment.
No. No skills, and the content was lacking. Mostly, I found the professor to be so upsetting that it really overshadowed everything.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: NA

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do the readings AFTER class and do them on time. And relax, you don't need to take any notes. His lecture notes are posted online. Take it only if you're interested in Population issues.
Don't bother. There are a few nuggets of wisdom but they're buried in a lot of garbage.
As an undergrad--it's probably a valuable course (though at times extremely uncomfortable). As a grad student--take something else instead.
The course is great, and not too work intensive. However, the reading load can be a bit heavy, so it would be good to do them regularly instead of just before an exam.

If you are an empty cup with no prior knowledge on the subject, it is an interesting area to be introduced to. If you are an analytical, independent thinker, don't take this class because your opinions won't be valued.
